One complaint I have is the percentage of the final being 30% standard across the math department. One teacher had the final worth 15%. Homeworks are fairly easy and you can work on them with friends so make sure to take advantage of that opportunity. One downside is that they are graded 1/2 for completion and 1/2 for accuracy with only 3-4 problems being graded in this manner. He doesn't post answer keys so if you got something wrong you could never know but still get a 100 on the homework. He does give decent partial credit with exams. 

If there were 3 exams each worth 15% and the final being worth the same I think it would make the class easier and put less stress on the students grade.

Excellent lecturer - explains concepts well, records every lecture, and posts notes. Exams are a mirror of what's on the homework and study guide. I only had to look over my previous homework and scan through the study guide solutions to do well on the exams. Additionally, Dr. Danul was very understanding, reasonable, and just a nice person in general. I was given extensions when appropriate.

Honestly, unless there is a scheduling conflict, you should take STAT400 with Dr. Danul.

Danul is without a doubt one of the better math teachers I've had. Quizzes every week are annoying, but if you can get Noorain as your TA because he is excellent with quiz prep. Exams are often similar to the practice exams, but ~ one problem each exam is something you haven't really seen before and requires critical thinking. Overall I'd say Danul is one of the better options for Calc 1.

Amazing professor who has really fair midterms and he also provides good review materials and practice for the final exam.  He also records lectures so although its helpful you do not have to attend. Discussions are also easy and although theres a quiz its very simple as TAs go over the concepts beforehand and you will get a good score as long as you stay up to date with the previous weeks topics. He also provided a decent curve at the end which helped a lot. Overall the class averages on the exams were really good and as long as you put in the work doing well in this class is very doable.

Having prior knowledge in calculus helps a lot in this class. i never attended lecture since it was recorded and posted online. The TA's are very helpful in discussion if you have any questions. The lectures are extremely boring and the study guides didn't help a ton so I would recommend just doing practice problems from the homeworks since they represented the exams a lot more. First exam I got a B+ and the other exams I got an A/A+ on both using this method. However the average was a B- for every exam so I assume he doesn't do the best job at preparing students for the exams.

I enjoyed these lectures a lot tbh. The professor speaks slowly enough that you have time to write everything down, and explains well with examples. He also posts notes and recordings in case you miss class or need to go back. I also just found the material interesting!

Homeworks can be kind of difficult, but are doable. Same for R projects. For both, go to office hours, discussion, and chat with friends in the class. (And my personal advice is to start the final HW and R project earlier - they are a LOT harder than previous ones!) 
The exams are not difficult if you are able to do the homework. Two of the three TAs were not good, but hopefully he will choose better in the future. 

Main criticism: assignments cannot be submitted past the due date unless you email the professor and ask. There’s no % off per day late policy like most teachers have. So, do your assignments on time!! People like me who start it the day it’s due will have some stress and trouble. But always email him if you need an extension because he will probably be nice about it.
knowledgeable, fairly patient during office hours, exact with proofs and math so explanations can be technical and feel overcomplicated, exams similar to homework

Decent professor. Lectures are recorded so you dont have to go to them, his lectures are similar to an audiobook of a textbook to be honest. His exams are very similar to the homework and study guide, so just memorize the questions from those and you will be perfectly fine on the exams. I haven't gone to class for two months and still ended with an A-. Additionally, by memorizing those, you can do well on the final. Imo, the discussions werent that helpful but also I did not go to them because I did not find them useful. Overall decent professor and really nice and always willing to help, just pay attention and do the homework and you will pass with flying colors.

I thought he was a good professor, sometimes he got wordy but overall he ensured students understood what he was explaining and when we ask questions he will clarify or explain further. The material was easy to understand but make sure you go to the discussions. The TAs explain the material we learned that week and there’s a quiz at the end but they were always very helpful.

Very kind and knowledgeable. Actually wants the students to succeed. The exams had no curve balls and if you studied the exam review and homework then you will do well. prior to this class i have never taken a stat class either.

Would give 4.5 if I could
Pros:
I honestly liked his lectures, they were easy to follow
I thought material was super interesting and explained stats and probability from ground up
straightforward exams, pretty much carbon copy of practice exams

Cons:
TAs kinda suck
R projects you pretty much had to learn and do by yourself but they weren't bad
Homeworks were sometimes MAD difficult for no reason and there was no answer key (but exams were way easier)
App there was more material than other stat teachers

Overall super solid professor, I learned a lot and class was not difficult by any means

Pros:
- Exams are very very close to the study guides/homeworks. No curveballs whatsoever.
- Pauses a lot during lecture to answer questions.
- Discussion is just TA’s going over homeworks and handing out homework answers. 8 homeworks per semester, 6 questions each (except the first one, which is 5 questions)
- Responds to emails promptly.

Cons:
- He often makes explanations wordy.
- Some parts of statistics require intuition (counting problems).
- Stats is very different from the math you are used to (calculus etc.) and will take some getting used to. Overall, I found this class more difficult than AP Calc BC.
- R projects are difficult and time consuming.

Fall '24: His lectures are frankly very boring but I can't really fault him for anything else. At the end of the day, the material was very digestible and the work was quite easy, particularly the exams which were a breeze. He also just seems like a nice guy and the course is set up well in the sense that he responds quickly to emails, records lectures, and uploads notes. You could do a lot worse.

I feel bad giving Mestiyage a low rating, as he really is a nice guy. Unfortunately the guy just cannot teach, and neither can his TAs. I learned most of the material from external resources as most websites are far better at explaining concepts intuitively than Mestiyage is. 

Additionally, the days of his exams being ripped straight from his practice materials appear to be over. That was not the case this semester.

Nice guy, very understanding, but genuinely one of the most boring professors I've had. Drew out points that could've been made in 2 minutes over entire lectures. I've never been someone who usually skips classes but he really tested my will to attend, I think these reviews definitely make him seem better than he is because he's nice but this class has not been a good experience, though the workload has been very easy.

Professor Danul is a great instructor. He explains concepts clearly and provides helpful examples during lectures. The exams are fair, and if you keep up with the homework and review the study guides, you should do well. I typically just re did the study guide the day before the exam and did fine (3 b+) One thing to keep in mind is that your experience can depend a lot on your Ta, some are more helpful than others, and unfortunately, mine struggled to explain the material clearly. That said, Professor Danul records all of his lectures, which is incredibly helpful. Since he speaks slowly and methodically, I often rewatch them at 2x speed, which works perfectly for reviewing the material.

For all of the MATH120 professors, he's the best from what I've heard. The course is divided up pretty nicely and isn't too rushed. He does explain things in technical terms at some points and that can make it hard to follow along, but the material itself is not hard if you put in work outside of class. He responds quickly to emails, uploads notes and study guides that are pretty similar to the exams and he seems like a nice guy. The weekly quizzes are also not that hard and follow the material done in class. However, the TAs at least in my class were literally no help at all, I'm not sure they understood the questions students were asking half the time, I only showed up to discussion to do the quizzes because the "help" from the TAs was little to none.

Nice guy, but one of the most boring teachers I've ever had. If you know the content you'll do well but if you have to learn it from him you'll probably be teaching it to yourself after a month in. I don't recommend him but he's not the worst.

Id say take him. He is a super nice professor. Yes he over explains a lot and makes things very wordy but his exams and homeworks are literally so easy if u do the study guide. Sometimes you have to teach yourself because he overcomplicates things a lot but usually the lectures are easy to follow. I was always so bad at math but this class never stressed me out. Take him you wont regret it.

Danul is a great guy and is very understanding. He can be a bit wordy at times but I know he means well. I almost failed pre-calc last semester so I was a bit worried coming into calc in the spring. However, as long as you do the study guides and re-watch lectures you'll be fine. The only thing I would complain about is that the textbook and the homework assignments would have content we wouldn't spend that much time on, so they didn't really become a resource to me for exams.

It took a few lectures for me to get used to his teaching style, but once I did the class was super easy. The study guides prepare you for the exams really well and the exams are fairly easy if you do study. The homework isn't an overwhelming amount, but the questions are usually a lot harder than what you would see on the exams. He uses MingPress which isn't a great platform as if you get a problem wrong it doesn't tell you the correct answer. The quizzes are also reasonable and if you study you'll do good. Overall I really recommend Danul for this course.

I honestly really liked Danul and I found that despite overexplaining problems and confusing some students, he's a great professor. You definitely need to come in with some knowledge on basic algebra, but it's fine because the quizzes during discussions always makes sure you to stay up to date with your basic math skills. If you study and learn how to answer all the questions on the study guides(literally learn how to do them because similar problems show up on exams), you will do so well in this class. It isn't difficult and all resources are handed to you in order to excel.

Professor Danul is a pretty good professor. Lectures were sometimes slow and a little iffy, but he was very helpful still. All lectures were recorded which was helpful.  Discussion was not helpful to me and it would honestly just confuse me more. This class wasn't that bad, my only complaints were the study guides never covered everything that would be on the exam. Also, we didn't finish the last topic for the final until like a class or two before it (we also had a quiz in discussion the week before which I found annoying). Other than that, he's a great prof. I didn't come into this class with any calculus experience and being extremely horrible at math, and still somehow clutched a b so I recommend!

Good professor—sometimes gets a bit wordy when explaining things, but overall he's clear and thorough. The exams are pretty similar to the study guides, which is helpful. One tip: while the study guide problems often result in whole number answers, a decent number of exam questions ended in fractions. Make sure you're comfortable working with those—especially when dealing with derivatives and similar topics, as it can get a little confusing even if you're confident in calculus.

Two of the lowest quiz grades are dropped, and the homework is fair. Lectures are recorded, so I rarely went to class, but I always attended discussion because of the quizzes.

He does a great job preparing you for the exams and genuinely wants his students to succeed.
Very great and understand professors. Gives you an hour after due dates to still turn in for full credit. Study guides are very helpful for the exam, and homework's and.R projects are all fair.

He is truly amazing and makes calc easy to learn. He is old fashion in the sense he uses pen and paper to do everything but it works for him. I never got less than an A on a midterm and he makes you very prepared for any midterm/final.

As a stats newbie, I loved STAT401 with Danul! His class is super organized, covering hypothesis tests, ANOVA, linear regression, and more at a perfect pace. Danul's notes are crystal clear, and he's a chill grader who gives homework extensions and cares about your success. Some tricky concepts could use clearer explanations, but stats is tough, so I get it. If you're at UMD, take his class! Pro tip: bring snacks to office hours. Danul's a snack king and he will be extremely grateful. Highly recommend!

Overall, I would say that he is a pretty good professor. Only thing I didn’t like was that he would sometimes over explain things that would end up taking 5 mins. Then this would lead him to rushing towards the end of the class, making things more confusing. Other than that, he answers all the students questions. His study guides for midterms are also very similar to what is actually on the exam (besides 1 question sometimes). There are also weekly quizzes in discussion (besides exam weeks). One thing about the TA though is that he would sometimes jump a few steps in calculating things which would then confuse some students. Other than that, I liked both the professor and TA.

Overall a fine professor. Has a bit of an accent but easy enough to understand. He definitely over explains things and over complicates simple topics. You will take a ton of notes in his class and he re-writes every problem even the wordy ones this causes him to have to rush toward the end of lecture. All his lectures are recorded which is nice. Gave good practice for midterm exams but did not give any practice material for the final besides old finals. (The questions change every year so it’s not a great representation). Responds to emails quickly. He is a fine professor having a high-school background in calculus will definitely be helpful as this is a pretty fast paced course.
Professor is great but seriously I never came to know what he expects in his subject. he would ask simple question but while checking he needs a lot of things and its very unintuitive.

Great professor, explains content well overall. Sometimes he rushes through examples but he's very receptive when you ask him to explain something again. Exams are super fair and homework is gone over in weekly discussions before due. Class can sometimes be a bit of a snoozefest but Danul is by far the best option for STAT400 and I would highly recommend him.

Assignments are almost free 100's, so it's down to the exams, which aren't too bad if you know your calculus (and can be bothered to study). He provides an extremely generous study guide with answers, and makes both his lecture recordings and writings accessible. No quizzes too, which is really nice.

As generous as the assignments are I felt like Danul explained concepts in lecture in extremely roundabout and confusing ways, and I personally found it better to learn from the TA or the textbook as a primary source, but also useful to peek at the lecture notes and such secondarily.

A goated professor who cares about students success and is very helpful. He is very lenient with grading and has fair exams but be sure to study as things could get tricky. 

PROS:
1) Good grading
2) Nice professor
3) Small class

CONS:
1) Not recored lecture
2) Somewhat theoretical at some points

I call him MDDKG and he is one mountain goat

In case you're wondering, Danul and Mestiyage are two of the names for the same guy. 

Nothing brilliant, nothing flawed about STAT400 with Gunatilleka. He has a system figured out, and it worked for me. Safest/least risky choice. 

- 30% final, 2x15% midterm, 3x4% R Project, 28% (~8) homework. 
- Homeworks discussed in Discussion, people actually go surprisingly
- R projects mildly annoying, but like the homeworks, a grade booster
- Exams had slightly lower than typical averages, but nothing crazy. There were four versions of each exam, so it was pretty formulaic without curveballs. 
- Lectures recorded, handwritten notes, ~20% attendance. Many places to learn the content. He's a fine teacher, speaks clearly, etc, so I went, and that was enough. Just don't think too deeply at times. That could cost you your sanity. We don't spend much time on derivations, so turn your brain off and apply the formulas.

super nice guy and curves the class at the end of the semester but i would have done terribly if i didn’t have a solid background in calc from high school. i felt like he made concepts much more complex than they had to be. a friend of mine in the class with me never took calc and definitely struggled because of his teaching

If you're taking math 120 and don't have the chance to take Gruber, then take Gunatilleka. He's a very nice professor who knows what he's teaching and teaches it well. We had weekly quizzes in discussion which were only made up of 2 questions. One being a basic algebra question ( that's why you need a good foundation in algebra) and the other was on the material we were learning. He posts all of his lecture videos and puts out a study guide before each exam (4 total exams). When it comes to making up work he's very lenient and will let you make the work if you have reason. the only downside is that the study guides don't always cover all the material for the exams so you have to deal with that.

TL;DR: Lectures can feel a bit slow or boring at times, but he genuinley cares about his students and is good and explaining things slowly

Pros:
 - Exams were very very similar to practice exams
 - Homeworks were a little tough, but doable
 - quizzes were either once a week or once every two weeks depending on how he was feeling. Usually similar to an example in class though, so they weren't bad if you showed up to class.
 - Genuinely great at explaining things starting from the basics and working up
 - Works almost 1:1 from the textbook, so even if you miss class, you can read the textbook to catch up.

Cons: 
 - Lectures can be kinda boring as he is a little monotone and lecutres can move slow a lot of the time.
The absolute goat. Explains material so well. Records all lectures. Exams are super fair. Homeworks are long but still fair. Take STAT401 with no one else but the legend Danul.
